title: i morning briefing : Why a bid to takeover the Telegraph resulted in a major row
body_text:
Welcome to Friday’s Early Edition from i.
“A free press is the unsleeping guardian of every other right that free men prize; it is the most dangerous foe of tyranny”. So goes the oft-cited Winston Churchill quote. In recent years Britain has come under increased scrutiny on the freedom of its press. Last year the World Press Freedom Index ranked the UK 26th in the world, highlighting “worrying legislative proposals, the approval of Julian Assange’s extradition to the United States, and the treatment of journalists covering protests”. A lack of pluralism in the media landscape is also often raised as a concern. But recently another perceived threat cropped up in the form of a potential buyout of the Daily Telegraph titles by a consortium backed by the UAE. The commotion over the proposal has now led to the decision to ban foreign governments from owning UK newspapers and magazines. Baroness Stowell, a former Conservative cabinet minister, said upholding the right of the press to hold “those of us in Parliament” to account “is what has prevented any UK Government from owning or controlling the press. It’s surely inconceivable then that we would sanction a foreign government state power to what no UK Government ever has nor would ever do.” What happened, what does it mean (and what has George Osborne got to do with it?). We’ll take a look after the headlines.
Today’s news, and why it matters
Metropolitan Police officers being investigated for misconduct could be allowed to continue to work without restrictions and remain eligible for promotion, a leaked memo from Sir Mark Rowley reveals. A Met Police officer told i Rowley’s comments were shocking to receive as they came only a week after Lady Elish Angiolini’s report exposed missed opportunities to stop PC Wayne Couzens.
The Government’s new definition of extremism is “potentially very dangerous” and risks the “reflecting the darkest regimes”, human rights experts have said. A professor of international law and human rights, Neve Gordon, told i the change in definition amounted to assessing groups by their “beliefs, not their actions”.
Penny Mordaunt emerging as Tory leadership contender to stop right-wing takeover. Moderates’ new favourite has been hammering the rubber chicken circuit. Her backers believe she can win over the grassroots, reports Arj Singh.
Liz Truss accepted a £20,000 trip to a little-known US right-wing conference on a private island attended by academic Jordan Peterson and prominent backers of Donald Trump, i can reveal. The former prime minister appeared at the event as part of her attempts to relaunch her political career by building bridges with US conservatives.
Funding social care should not be taken out of the hands of cash-strapped councils and there is no quick fix for the struggling sector, a Government minister has said. Helen Whately told i she did not think social care funding should be centralised to mirror the NHS – arguing that local authorities know best what care people need.
Props from the disastrous Willy Wonka event in Glasgow, which were found in a bin, have raised more than £2,000 at auction for a Palestinian aid charity.
Three questions over the Telegraph takeover row:
- What happened? Redbird IMI, an investment fund majority-owned by Sheikh Mansour bin Zayed Al Nahyan, vice president of the United Arab Emirates and owner of Manchester City Football Club, had proposed a £1.2bn deal to takeover the Daily Telegraph and the Spectator. RedBird IMI had pledged to maintain editorial freedoms at The Telegraph, with an advisory board to rule on disputes between journalists and the owners in the UAE. Other bidders for the titles included hedge-fund tycoon and GB News owner Paul Marshall, and Daily Mail owner DMGT. But pressure on the Government to stop the UAE-backed takeover ramped up, and Sunak’s administration faced a possible defeat in the House of Lords from peers who wanted to see action. Conservative peer Baroness Fleet, a former editor of the London Evening Standard, said: “I know that anyone who buys a newspaper wants to influence society, politicians and Government. All proprietors interfere”. She added: “I go even further and say that one of the reasons perhaps why a foreign government would want to buy an important newspaper such as the Telegraph would be to promote an anti-Israel, pro-Palestinian point of view.” Staff on the titles had expressed deep concern too. Veteran editor and broadcaster Andrew Neil, who is also chairman of the Spectator, had previously called the deal “absurd”. He said: “We are a democracy; our publications are part of the democratic process. How could we be owned by an undemocratic government?” Fraser Nelson, editor of the Spectator, also warned that preserving a free press “means keeping governments and publications apart”. Yesterday the Government indicated it would amend legislation to stop overseas state ownership, influence or control of newspapers and periodical magazines.
- What is the ban? The Government has said it will bring forward an amendment to the Digital Markets, Competition and Consumers Bill that would block such deals. Speaking in the Lords, media minister Lord Parkinson of Whitley Bay said: “The Government is committed to bringing forward an amendment to this Bill at third reading which prevents foreign state ownership of newspapers. We will amend the media merger regime explicitly to rule out newspaper and periodical news magazine mergers involving ownership, influence or control by foreign states.” The government will publish full details of its legislation next Tuesday. It could apply to the Telegraph Media Group takeover if the law was passed swiftly, Lord Parkinson suggested. Read more here.
- What was George Osborne’s role? The former Chancellor is a partner at Robey Warshaw, the investment fund hired by RedBird IMI to help secure the Telegraph deal. But with the deal now apparently “dead” insiders have spoken out. “George Osborne has failed to make this work,” one told i. “He was brought on by RedBird to land this deal precisely because he is thought to be able to manage Tories and he knows the media business.” Andrew Neil told i: “We need to put a little shrine up to [CNN boss Jeff] Zucker and George Osborne whose totally cack-handed handling of this takeover attempt has given us greater protection from foreign governments than we’ve ever had before. What Osborne has done is quite a remarkable achievement; there was a coalition against the deal stretching from Lee Anderson to [Green MP] Caroline Lucas. I take my hat off to him. I know that wasn’t his intention but no one has created a coalition this wide since we fought the Nazis.” Read the full story here.
Around the world
The movement of a pilot’s seat on a Boeing 787 Dreamliner may have been behind the aircraft’s sudden nosedive during a flight that caused the injury of at least 50 passengers, according to an aviation publication. A flight deck seat is now one focus of the investigation into the incident, Air Current reported.
This weekend, Russia is going to the polls in a sham election that we all know Vladimir Putin will win by a landslide. But the elections potentially mark a new stage in his rule and could also end up having the opposite effect from that intended, undermining rather than bolstering the legitimacy of his regime, writes Mark Galeotti.
Pierce Brosnan pleaded guilty Thursday to stepping off a trail in a thermal area during a November visit to Yellowstone national park. Brosnan was fined $500 and ordered to make a $1,000 donation to Yellowstone Forever – a non-profit organisation that supports the park – by 1 April, court records showed.
A British Airways Concorde jet has been transported across the Hudson River and back to a museum in New York after undergoing a seven-month restoration.
Watch out for…
A debate on Liz Truss’ transgender law reforms, which would bar “biological males” from female-only spaces, such as changing rooms and toilets, along with preventing them from competing in women’s sport and stopping children from attempting to change their gender.
Thoughts for the day
Diane Abbott is the start of a very awkward year for Labour. What goes around has a habit of coming back around when politicians hurl hypocrisy charges, warns Anne McElvoy.
Harry was right: Prince William’s stubbornness is extraordinary. It may not be such a bad thing in a monarch, says Jennie Bond.
Having kids ruined my career – and I’m glad. How refreshing to hear from Lily Allen that her choice to raise her kids stopped her career progression, writes Julie Cook.
Culture Break
‘I’m bewildered by Western religions. True faith is riddled with doubt’. Cate Blanchett talks about filming her first starring role in her native Australia for nearly two decades, and hoping for a miracle.
The Big Read
The trespassers fighting for a ‘right to roam’ across England’s countryside. Walkers shut out of thousands of beauty spots, say campaigners -but landowners say law change would see sites overrun with visitors, reports Adam Forrest.
Sport
Chelsea’s loans have dried up – now Vitesse Arnhem are in deep trouble. For almost a decade, Vitesse were a hot-bed for bright young talent with Chelsea the chief beneficiary. Now their future looks pretty bleak, writes Daniel Storey.
Something to brighten your day
10 ways to fake a clean house. Experts share their secrets with Anna Bonet to giving the illusion of a polished home.
